title: Some wildly interesting stuff here ...
content:
... represented in some very poorly compressed jpegs. I ran across this page by accident when googling Wim Crouwel. There's a fair bit of stuff I haven't seen before, presumably all scanned from books (the page looks like a resource from a lecture course in Communications Design). Original drawings by Tschichold for Sabon, type specimens from Nebiolo, some of Giovanni Pintorini's lovely ad designs for Olivetti ...   
   
 [http://www.mosne.lacab.it/art-design/dispense/scudero/B/dispensaB.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20100317145514/http:/www.mosne.lacab.it/art-design/dispense/scudero/B/dispensaB.html)   
   
Enjoy!   
   
Robert
author: rjohnston

comments.content:
What a trippy collection.   
Those Olivetti Chinese crop-circle thingies are amazing.   
   
But to me this (~55% down the page - yes, I measured) takes the cake:   
   
 ![fodor](http://web.archive.org/web/20100317145514im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/30/33873.gif)   
   
Really, what the hell could those bitmap patterns mean?! The only stuff I can think of that can explain it is prescient (assuming it was done a while ago).   
   
hhp

Pretty sure that's Crouwel. He did a bunch of experiments with grid-based type in the 60s (I'm sure you know the New Alphabet -- the Foundry have a nice digital version).   
   
That one, though, really is as you say: trippy.   
   
R

A shame about the compression.   
Try this: Put on your earphones, crank it up, grab that scroller thing, unfocus you eyes and start scrolling, the first millisecond or two you'll be superinspired, then your mind just blows.

You can get a sense of Wim Crouwel here in this book:

[http://youworkforthem.com/product.php?sku=P0068](http://web.archive.org/web/20100317145514/http:/youworkforthem.com/product.php?sku=P0068 "http://youworkforthem.com/product.php?sku=P0068")

They actually show you some of the pages inside the book. Having the book in hand is better of course - but here is a taste. Wim is wonderful.

There's some hilarious stuff in [Piet Schreuders](http://web.archive.org/web/20100317145514/http:/www.xs4all.nl/~maxb/eye32-schreuders.htm)' book   
"Lay In - Lay Out" (which should be mandatory literature   
for graphic design students BTW) about Crouwel's grid-   
based experiments. He has a fair stab at the [New Alphabet](http://web.archive.org/web/20100317145514/http:/www.foundrytypes.co.uk/foundry_architype_3/archi_3_new_alpha1.html),   
or 7/3/11/3/7 as it was originally called: (my translation)   
   
_"This text set in Crouwel's 7/3/11/3/7, a typeface originally   
conceived to be read by optical text recognition, was   
submitted to such an OCR program in 1996, which resulted   
in the following:

(and so and so on I'm getting a headache - ed.)   
_How intriguing it might be, the general sense of this text still
